docs.lead_paragraph: On March 15, 1960, an 18-year-old German girl and her younger brother boarded a train here to escape East German Communism for the West. But the police were patrolling and the girl, convinced they could not make it together, pushed the boy off the train as it started to move. ''Police were asking me who I was, where I was going, why I was traveling, and I realized we were too suspicious as a pair,'' said Heidi Boettcher, now an American citizen. ''My brother was just 16. I was sure he would join me later.''

headline.main: Siblings' Lives Trace a U.S.-German Divide

docs.abstract: Article in series One Europe, 10 Years, examining Europe decade after fall of Berlin Wall, focuses on Heidi Schulz-Netzer and her brother Hans, East Germans who were seperated in 1960 when Heidi escaped to West; notes that Heidi is American citizen living on Missouri farm with her husband, Junior Boettcher, and that they have 14 grandchildren; says Hans was reunited with his sister in 1991, when he traveled to US for first time; map; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: There is a soft side and a hard side to Richard L. Huber, Aetna's chief executive, both recently in evidence. The soft side: ''Here we are in probably the most unprecedented period of prosperity this nation has ever had, and there are still numerous pockets of poverty,'' he said after serving as a host to President Clinton in Hartford, where Aetna is based, last Thursday. The president was there promoting inner-city economic development. Mr. Huber has moved into a gritty neighborhood, fixed up surrounding buildings and attracted scores of other residents.
docs.abstract: Aetna chief executive Richard L Huber showed his soft side, by promoting inner-city economic development, as well as hard side, by disparaging fellow lawyer Richard Scruggs, who is working on patients' suits against Aetna and other managed-care providers (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: 'Allergies, I am told, don't flare up the first time you come in contact with the offending agent,'' writes Tom Wolfe, author of the novels ''Bonfire of the Vanities'' and ''A Man in Full.'' ''The allergens build up gradually over time until one day you can't take it anymore.'' That's a writer's way of beginning a letter. None of this right-to-the-point e-mail stuff, or apologies for belatedness, or arch ''anent: whatever.'' On the contrary, a letter that begins with an apt metaphor or an original turn of phrase causes the recipient to sit back and prepare to enjoy the vanishing art of correspondence.

headline.main: The Way We Live Now: 11-07-99: On Language; Pushing It

docs.lead_paragraph: IMAGINE that you're a trial lawyer. You've noticed that Americans are getting fatter, and that the government blames obesity and inactivity for more than 300,000 premature deaths every year. You've also noticed that scientists believe fatty foods kill people, and that fast-food outlets are selling cheeseburgers with both hands. You pilot your late-model Mercedes into the drive-through lane, risking grease stains on the leather upholstery. You make a purchase and discover that fast-food packaging is mute as to a more important risk. Nowhere does it say that eating a bucket of hot wings could result in serious injury or death.
docs.abstract: Daniel Akst On the Contrary column compares litigation against tobacco industry with imaginary suit filed against fast-food industry for harming people by selling cheeseburgers that have potential of causing heart disease and deaths; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: My decision to leave the corporate world and sell books on Sixth Avenue in Greenwich Village was incomprehensible to my family and friends. Early on, a former co-worker spotted me standing behind my book table one evening and asked in a tone of comic disbelief, ''So this is what you're doing now?'' ''No,'' I replied, embarrassed. ''I'm just watching the stuff for a friend of mine. He went to the bathroom.'' I had gone into exile on the street, a process that began long before I ever had a book table on Sixth Avenue. In an attempt to avoid the everyday racism of corporate life, I had been working as a legal proofreader on the night shift at the law firm Robinson Silverman. Nothing made the futility of my efforts more evident to me than an incident that occurred one evening when I had no work to do because of a coming holiday. I sat at a secretary's workstation and read a copy of Business Week. A white attorney walked over to me, leaned over my shoulder and began to read. The crumbs from the popcorn he was eating fell on my head. I thought to myself, ''Man, I should stand up and slap this guy senseless.'' But I did not say a word to him. My silence was simply another in a series of concessions I made to those who provided me with my daily bread.
docs.abstract: Hakim Hasan article on his decision to make a living selling books on the street in Greenwich Village; says that he was fleeing racism of white corporate world and that now, after seven years of street vending, he is seeking more stable employment; he is subject of Mitchell Duneier's forthcoming book, Sidewalk (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IS there life after leaving I.B.M.? Four former executives who voluntarily although reluctantly took early retirement from International Business Machines Corporation a decade or so ago weighed that question recently. All of them concluded that since leaving I.B.M., their lives, with financial security and free time, had become enriched through a mix of travel, volunteering and developing jobs that kept sharp the skills they had learned at I.B.M.

headline.main: Life on the Other Side of I.B.M.

docs.abstract: Profiles of Zora Easton, Stanley Freid, Scott Shaw and Victor Wakefield, four former International Business Machines executives who voluntarily although reluctantly took early retirement a decade ago; all conclude that financial security and free time have enriched their lives; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the day before Halloween, Miguelina Vasquez went to the Kmart here to find costumes for her two children. On the way over to the aisle with the vampire masks, she stopped to sign up the children for government-financed health insurance. Ms. Vasquez, a New Brunswick resident, is a single mother who earns $200 a week working for Tommy Hilfiger Inc. in Edison. She had applied for Medicaid but was rejected. For the last two years, when her children have fallen ill, she has been taking them to a health center in New Brunswick. She owes the center $800 and has no idea how she will pay the bill.

headline.main: In One Stop, Kmart and Health Insurance

docs.abstract: Kidcare, provider of low-cost health insurance for children that is funded with combination of federal and state funds, sets up table in Kmart in Somerset, NJ, to sign up families; other states have similar programs; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Overpriced Medications'' (letter, Nov. 1):
docs.abstract: Carl Weber, president of Westchester County Medical Society, replies to Nov 1 letter about price of medications, saying it is better to encourage a profitable and innovative drug industry that has improved therapies and increased efficiency of care than to support a profiteering and restrictive managed care industry
